text: it's now physically impossible to leave
on the 29th of March wait for ages we've
talked about the 29th of March as the
day brexit will happen under the rules
of article 50 which sets the timetable
for a country to leave the EU we are out
at 11 p.m. UK time on that day but with
brexit things are never that simple
firstly a few things need to happen
before then if mp's back a brexit deal
which would have to be different to the
one they've already voted on then
Parliament will have to pass the
withdrawal agreement bill which would
put it into effect not a quick and easy
process so it's likely a bit of extra
time would be needed leaving without a
deal would mean more laws need to be
passed covering areas currently governed
by the EU like trade farming and
immigration I see the right 412 the nose
to the left 202 so the eyes have it the
eyes have it a lot and then there's the
fact that Parliament has voted to delay
the brexit process although that's not
technically binding on the government it
does make it much more likely the EU has
to agree to any delay though and the
Prime Minister is expected to ask for an
extension
brexit e is worried that could mean the
UK is left stuck in a long delay with no
clear plan for leaving others see it as
a chance to negotiate a different closer
relationship with the EU so for a long
time we've heard to resume saying things
like this absolute focus should be on
working to get a deal and leaving on the
29th of March but things have changed
and one way or another a delay beyond
the 29th of March now looks likely
